title: Not-so-basic base R functions
text:
R is known for its versatility and extensive collection of packages. As of the publishing of this post, there are over 23 thousand packages on R-universe. But what if I told you that you could do some pretty amazing things without loading any packages at all?
There‚Äôs a lot of love for base R, and I am excited to pile on. In this blog post, I will explore a few of my favorite not-so-basic base R functions using webR. Click ‚ÄòRun code‚Äô to see them in action!

title: Not-so-basic base R functions
text:
1. invisible()
The invisible() function ‚Äúreturns a temporarily invisible copy of an object‚Äù. Below, we have examples where the functions return their argument, but one does so invisibly.


Resources

invisible documentation
StackOverflow discussion
Tidyverse design guide

The way to see invisible output is by saving to a variable or running print(). Both of the below will print:

    webR...
  
    
    
      
    
  
  
  


If you‚Äôre writing functions, then invisible() can be very helpful. In fact, many of your favorite functions use invisible(). For example, readr::write_csv() invisibly returns the data frame that was saved.

In the example below, using {purrr} and tidytab::tab2() together results in two NULL list items that I do not need.

First, let‚Äôs install the required R packages. This should be quick, not enough time to go get a cup of coffee! Installing purrr from the webR binary repository is as easy as calling webr::install().

For a slightly more difficult installation, let‚Äôs install the R package tidytab, which is compiled into a WebAssembly binary on r-universe.

Running invisible() eliminates that!

  üü° Loading
    webR...
  
    
    
      
    
  
  
  



When writing a function, R can print a lot of stuff implictly. Per the Tidyverse design guide, ‚Äúif a function is called primarily for its side-effects, it should invisibly return a useful output‚Äù.

This is useful for generating intermediate diagnostics or for saving multiple output formats.

The noquote() function ‚Äúprints character strings without quotes.‚Äù

I use noquote() in a function that converts Markdown reference-style links into HTML links. Below, I pipe a Markdown reference-style link ("[Isabella's blog](ivelasq.rbind.io)") into an anonymous function to get the HTML version that‚Äôs not surrounded by quotes, allowing me to paste it directly in the text (<a href="ivelasq.rbind.io" target = "_blank">Isabella's blog</a>).


Learn more about this syntax in my previous blog post!

3. coplot
The coplot() function allows you to create conditioning plots. With these plots, you can quickly explore pairs of variables conditioned on a third.
